title: Cat. 55.4  Maruru (Offerings of Gratitude), 1893/94
publication_title: Gauguin Paintings, Sculpture, and Graphic Works at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Maruru (Offerings of Gratitude), from the Noa Noa Suite  
1893/94  
Third state of three  
Wood-block print, printed twice in yellow ocher and black inks, over a yellow ink tone block, and transferred golden-yellow, green, and orange oil-based media, some containing beeswax and conifer resin (probably pine resin), with brush and black ink and diluted yellow printing ink, on cream Japanese paper; 206 × 357 mm (image); 235 × 394 mm (sheet)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Edward McCormick Blair, 2002.249  
Guérin 24, Kornfeld III/III, B  
For the verso, see fig. 55.4.1

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section technical_report" id="technical_report">One of the most inventive printing campaigns of the late nineteenth century, Gauguin’s Noa Noa Suite distinguishes itself as an enterprise in which the artist worked freely and experimentally with a wide range of papers, disparate media, and unconventional printing and transfer techniques to produce a multitude of impressions. Having purchased ten end-grain boxwood blocks of the highest quality, suitable for both wood engraving with a needle and wood carving with variously shaped gouges and knives, the artist printed all ten blocks as a group at several distinct moments in the block-carving process. He did so in a series of working campaigns, in which he would print the blocks, then revise them, then print them again. Different methods and materials were used in each campaign. These include applications of transparent watercolor washed over printed images; site-specific transfer of opaque, resinous, and waxy media from sheets of glass onto the paper before printing; and multiple, deliberately off-register printings in various inks on single sheets of paper. Close examination of a large number of examples has led to a chronology of print production that chronicles the artist’s more rudimentary printing methods as well as unconventional printing techniques in which atypical materials were used at different moments in the evolution of the suite.

Gauguin’s ingenuity is nowhere better represented than in the group of prints that he produced by combining traditional wood-block printing methods with complex media-transfer techniques, as in this third—and final—state impression of Maruru (Offerings of Gratitude). The group spans the entire Noa Noa Suite, with representative impressions printed with the same combination of materials and techniques from each of the ten blocks. After satisfactorily arriving at final compositions on the blocks, the artist ceased carving and focused his efforts on printing multilayered applications of color using oil-based media, some that contained beeswax and conifer resin (probably pine resin) in one layer, colored printing inks in another, and black and colored inks in one or more printings of the block on top of them.

The multilayer interactive image viewer is designed to facilitate the viewer’s exploration and comparison of the technical images (fig. 55.4.2).

Four different layers of media are present in this print. Chrome yellow printing ink was applied first by means of transfer from a piece of glass. The printing ink used for this layer has a fluid appearance, and was applied evenly over much of the block. Oil-based media containing some beeswax was then transferred on top of it. Chrome yellow, vermilion, emerald green, and orange (a mixture of vermilion and chrome yellow or chrome orange) were applied to specific areas by means of transfer from the glass (see fig. 55.4.3 and fig. 55.4.4). Atop these two layers of colored media, the block was printed twice, first in an iron oxide–containing printing ink that is likely deep yellow ocher, then in carbon black printing ink that contains some Prussian blue.

The good-quality, medium-weight Japanese paper is well sized with a slight sheen overall that is visible in raking light. Long paper fibers are visible under magnification and in transmitted light an irregular shu (mold) impression can be seen. The left edge is deckled. The right and bottom edges are irregularly hand torn, although at first glance they appear to be deckled as well. The top of the sheet has a hard straight-cut edge. There is a significant amount of paper remaining around the printed image. The sheet has a slightly warm gray cast due to discoloration and embedded surface dirt. It is identical to the paper used to print an impression of Nave nave fenua (Delightful Land) (cat. 56.3). In both impressions the blocks were printed twice over a bright yellow tone block, and additional media were added by means of transfer.

For the verso of this sheet, see fig. 55.4.1.

206 × 357 mm (image); 235 × 394 mm (sheet)

This impression was printed in three layers. The first layer of media applied to the paper was bright chrome yellow, and it was applied overall by means of transfer from another source, traditionally called a tone block, used to establish the base tone. This source could have been another piece of paper, or another wood block; however, it is more likely that Gauguin used a piece of glass for this purpose. The use of a tone block is confirmed by the presence of yellow in the distant sky, in the tree behind the idol, and in the foreground forms; all have been applied site specifically to the paper. The second layer of transferred media is oil based and may contain some beeswax. It has a waxy consistency and its deposition is also loosely site specific. There are passages of emerald green in the tree (fig. 55.4.5), orange in the distant sky, background and idol, and yellow in the kapok seeds in the foreground. Using glass to transfer the media, the artist achieved site specificity. By placing the glass over the block he accurately located where he wanted to deposit media.

Ocher and black inks were printed successively over the transferred media. One printing is deliberately off register from the other by 1 mm in the horizontal direction. Much of the ocher printing that underlies the black is obscured by it. The black ink was rolled onto the block in two passes. Ink deposition in some areas is intensely black while in others it is uneven and spotty. Gauguin rolled the ink onto the block moving from right to left, lifting the roller prematurely as he approached the left edge, inadvertently creating a 10 mm vertical band of irregularly deposited ink (fig. 55.4.6). Elsewhere, thin areas of ink deposition appear in the background to the right of the palm tree and extend across the sheet to the idol’s head and feet. In his final touches, the artist took a rag and deliberately wiped black ink from the block in these same areas (fig. 55.4.7).

Once printed, Gauguin reworked the impression with brush and black wash. Today this wash has a silvery appearance, perhaps due to fading of some component of the ink (fig. 55.4.8). He applied it with a dry brush in wispy curved strokes to cast into shadow the large lobe of the tree to the left of the idol (fig. 55.4.9), and he added emphatic lines to the three figures in the foreground. Examination of passages where black ink bled through to the verso reveals that the artist reworked all of the forms in the foreground to cast them further into darkness. In an unusual step in his process, Gauguin hand applied touches of yellow media, presumed to be thinned printing ink, with his finger, and where the black ink was not yet dry, he blended the yellow with it (fig. 55.4.10). Because the black ink passages read as silver, the yellow areas feature much more prominently than originally intended by the artist. It is likely that when Gauguin completed his work on this impression, he had established extreme contrasts of light and dark by thrusting the middle ground into darkness and illuminating the rest with yellow light emanating from over the distant mountains (fig. 55.4.11). Whether this change was intended or a way to repair an unintended printing flaw along the left side of the sheet is not known.

In anticipation of exhibition in 2002, the print underwent conservation treatment. Surface dirt, old hinges, paper tapes, and adhesive residues were removed.

The print is in good condition. There are vertical printing creases approximately 30 mm long along the right edge of the image and two longer creases 90 mm long in the center of the sheet. All edges have darkened slightly, and the margins have grayed with embedded surface dirt. Intermittent foxing is visible in the margins and on the verso of the sheet.  
Harriet K. Stratis with the assistance of Mary Broadway

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section provenance" id="provenance">Sir Michael Ernest Sadler (1861–1943), Oxford.

Sold at Sotheby's, New York, to Alice Adam Ltd., Chicago, for Edward McCormick Blair (1915–2010), Chicago, Nov. 19, 1982, lot 104.

Given by Edward McCormick Blair to the Art Institute of Chicago, 2002.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section other_documentation" id="other_documentation">Signed in wood block, lower right, printed in white-line manner: PGO

Inscribed in wood block, lower right, printed in white-line manner: MARURU

Inscribed upper left, in graphite: M. Sadler esq.

Inscribed upper right, in graphite: 8

Inscribed lower right, in graphite, partially erased: Gauguin Maruru

Inscribed upper left, in graphite: M. E. Sadler / University College / Oxford

Inscribed lower left, in graphite: S. 420

Inscribed lower left, in graphite: 2002.249

The media and their application, as well as the condition of the artwork, were assessed through visual examination using normal, transmitted, and raking light; microscope magnification (8–10×), and ultraviolet-light examination (254 and 365 nm). The pigments in the printing inks and oil media were identified by XRF, Raman microspectroscopy, macro-XRF, and FTIR. The nature of the organic media was determined by THM-py-GCMS.

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">The locations of eight blocks from the Noa Noa Suite are known. Embossed into the verso of each is the trade name of the manufacturer, Kiessling. The manufacturer’s stamp reads: Kiessling / J Lacroix Suc / PARIS / D 089. Blocks for Maruru (Offerings of Gratitude) (cat. 55.1) and Manao tupapau (She Thinks of the Ghost or The Ghost Thinks of Her) (cat. 60.1) are in the Art Institute’s collection. The block for Noa Noa (cat. 51) is in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, and is described as fruitwood, possibly pearwood. The blocks for Te po (The Night) (cat. 52), Auti te pape (Women at the River) (cat. 59), and Nave nave fenua (Delightful Land) (cat. 56) are in the collection of the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. The block for L’univers est créé (The Universe Is Being Created) (cat. 54) is in the Memorial Art Gallery, University of Rochester, New York. The block for Mahna no varua ino (The Devil Speaks) (cat. 57) resides in the Bibliothèque Nationale de France, Paris. Gauguin repurposed two blocks from the suite, Te atua (The God) (cat. 53) and Te faruru (Here We Make Love) (cat. 58), by cutting them down and using the backs for a series of smaller prints that he made during his last years in Paris and upon his return to Tahiti in 1895. Two of the segments from the block for Te faruru are in the Národní Galerie, Prague. The segments from the block used for Te atua are presently lost.

I am grateful to Peter Zegers for so generously sharing his insights into the Noa Noa Suite. See Peter Kort Zegers, “In the Kitchen with Paul Gauguin: Devising Recipes for a Symbolist Graphic Aesthetic,” in The Broad Spectrum: Studies in Materials, Techniques, and Conservation of Color on Paper, ed. Harriet K. Stratis and Britt Salvesen (Archetype, 2002), pp. 138–44.

It is possible that this oil-based medium, which does not resemble printing ink, came directly from the palette that Gauguin used for his paintings. He did not produce these prints in isolation from the artworks that he was producing in other media in his studio. Paintings analyzed for this publication were found to contain original wax coatings (see, for example, Te raau rahi [The Big Tree] [cat. 27]), and several publications cite Gauguin’s use of wax and resin in his paint mixtures. See, for example, Carol Christensen, “The Painting Materials and Techniques of Paul Gauguin,” Conservation Research, ed. Ross M. Merrill, Studies in the History of Art, Monograph Series 2, vol. 41 (National Gallery of Art, Washington, D.C., 1993), pp. 63–103.

Using the toolbar at the bottom right, any two images of the artwork may be selected for comparison by clicking the layers icon to the right of the slider bar. The slider bar may be moved to transition back and forth between the two chosen images. Where annotations are available, the jagged-line icon brings up a list of them, or colored lines that show the significant features visible in each image, which may be turned on or off in any combination. For example, the red annotation lines, associated with the natural-light image, trace some of the artwork’s key compositional features. When overlaid onto a technical image (X-ray, raking light, ultraviolet, etc.), the red outlines help the viewer to better observe how features in the technical image relate to or diverge from the artwork as seen with the naked eye. (When annotations are turned on, a legend appears in the upper right showing each color and its associated image type.) The circular-arrow icon returns the image to the default settings (natural light, full-image view, natural-light [red] annotation on). The four-arrow icon toggles between the view of the image in the page and a full-screen view of the image. In the upper right corner, the vertical slider bar may be moved to zoom into or out of the image; different parts of the image can be accessed by clicking and dragging within the image itself. The icon in the upper left corner opens a small view of the full image, within which a red box indicates the portion of the overall image being viewed when zooming is enabled.

This method of transfer is clearly the precursor to the watercolor and oil transfer methods that Gauguin adopted moving forward (see, for example, cat. 68 and cat. 124). See Peter Kort Zegers, “In the Kitchen with Paul Gauguin: Devising Recipes for a Symbolist Graphic Aesthetic,” in The Broad Spectrum: Studies in Materials, Techniques, and Conservation of Color on Paper, ed. Harriet K. Stratis and Britt Salvesen (Archetype, 2002), pp. 138–44.

The organic media were analyzed using THM-Py-GCMS and found to be an oil-based medium with beeswax present here. Céline Daher, THM-Py-GCMS analytical results summary, Dec. 2015, on file in the Department of Conservation and Science, Art Institute of Chicago.

Pigment analysis carried out by Céline Daher is gratefully acknowledged; Daher, XRF, Raman microspectroscopy, macro-XRF, and FTIR analytical results summary, Dec. 2015, on file in the Department of Conservation and Science, Art Institute of Chicago.

I am grateful to Peter Zegers for so generously sharing with me his observations about Gauguin’s use of glass and for his insights into the Noa Noa Suite of wood-block prints.

The organic media were analyzed using THM-Py-GCMS and found to be an oil-based medium with beeswax and Pinaceae resin present in different amounts in various prints. Céline Daher, THM-Py-GCMS analytical results summary, Dec. 2015, on file in the Department of Conservation and Science, Institute of Chicago.

This is very much in keeping with the lighting effects he achieved in Maruru (cat. 55.2) and Nave nave fenua (Delightful Land) (cat. 56.1). See recolorizations of these two works.

Mary Cropley, condition report, Mar. 1988; Harriet K. Stratis, technical report and photographic documentation, June 1990; David Chandler, condition report, 1996; Kristi Dahm, condition report, 2004; Mary Broadway, condition report, treatment record, and photographic documentation, Mar. 2015; all in the conservation object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago. Broadway carried out the most recent conservation treatment, which greatly improved the appearance of the sheet.

Collector’s stamp of Michael Ernest Sadler (Lugt 1915c) on verso. Also according to Sotheby’s, New York, Nineteenth and Twentieth Century, Old Master and Contemporary Prints, sale cat. (Sotheby’s, New York, Nov. 18, 1982), lot 104.

Alice Adam Ltd., Chicago, invoice addressed to Edward Blair, Sr., Nov. 19, 1982, curatorial object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago.

</section><section id="figures">Cat. 55.4 Maruru (Offerings of Gratitude), from the Noa Noa Suite, 1893/94.

fig. 55.4.2 Gauguin’s Maruru (Offerings of Gratitude) (1893/94). The Art Institute of Chicago, 1948.253. Interactive image.

fig. 55.4.3 Gauguin’s Maruru (Offerings of Gratitude) (1893/94) with annotations identifying the pigments and the organic media, the areas selected for analysis, and the scientific methods used in their identification. The Art Institute of Chicago, 2002.249.

fig. 55.4.4 Top left, Gauguin’s Maruru (Offerings of Gratitude) (1893/94). Elemental mapping identified pigments and determined media distribution across the sheet. White areas indicate the presence of, top right, chromium (present in chrome yellow pigment); bottom left, copper (present in a copper-containing green pigment); and bottom right, mercury (present in vermilion pigment).

fig. 55.4.5 Detail of Gauguin’s Maruru (Offerings of Gratitude) (1893/94) showing the emerald green in the tree behind the idol. The Art Institute of Chicago, 2002.249.

fig. 55.4.6 Detail, lower left, of Gauguin’s Maruru (Offerings of Gratitude) (1893/94) showing the uneven application of black ink along the left edge of the image, which the artist covered with selectively applied additional media. The Art Institute of Chicago, 2002.249.

fig. 55.4.7 Detail, center, of Gauguin’s Maruru (Offerings of Gratitude) (1893/94) showing an instance in which the artist used a rag to wipe black ink from the block before he printed it so that the underlying colors would remain visible. The Art Institute of Chicago, 2002.249.

fig. 55.4.8 Detail, center, of Maruru (Offerings of Gratitude) (1893/94) showing an area where the artist went back into the printed image and brush applied strokes of black media that now appears silver-gray. The Art Institute of Chicago, 2002.249.

fig. 55.4.9 Detail of Gauguin’s Maruru (Offerings of Gratitude) (1893/94) showing an area in the tree where Gauguin used minimal amounts of black media that now appears silver-gray with a dry brush to create curved, wispy shadows. The Art Institute of Chicago, 2002.249.

fig. 55.4.10 Detail, upper left, of Gauguin’s Maruru (Offerings of Gratitude) (1893/94) showing an area where the artist likely used his fingers to blend yellow printing ink into the black before it was fully dry, perhaps to minimize the appearance of a printing flaw. The Art Institute of Chicago, 2002.249.

fig. 55.4.11 Detail, upper left, of Gauguin’s Maruru (Offerings of Gratitude) (1893/94) showing a fluid bright chrome yellow sky in the background dotted with more dimensional golden-yellow oil-based media containing wax and resin. The Art Institute of Chicago, 2002.249.

fig. 55.4.1 Verso of Gauguin’s Maruru (Offerings of Gratitude), from the Noa Noa Suite (1893/94). The Art Institute of Chicago, 1948.253.

</section>
